pullRequest.body:
We define a relative CW-complex as the colimit of an expanding sequence of subspaces `sk i` (called the $(i-1)$-skeleton) for `i ≥ 0`, where `sk 0` (i.e., the $(-1)$-skeleton) is an arbitrary topological space, and each `sk (n + 1)` (i.e., the $n$-skeleton) is obtained from `sk n` (i.e., the $(n-1)$-skeleton) by attaching `n`-disks.

This is based on [David Wärn's suggestion on Zulip](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Do.20we.20have.20CW.20complexes.3F/near/231769080) and Chapter 10 of _[A Concise Course in Algebraic Topology](https://www.math.uchicago.edu/~may/CONCISE/ConciseRevised.pdf)_ by J. P. May.

Co-authored-by: Elliot Dean Young <infinitychernweil@gmail.com>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

- [x] depends on: #16672 [for moving `sphere` and `disk` to `TopCat/Basic.lean`]

I'd like to ask:

1. Is it appropriate to define `RelativeCWComplex` with a skeleton `sk i` for each integer `i`? Although we only need `sk i` for `i ≥ -1`, strictly sticking to `i ≥ -1` causes some trouble with dependent type theory in my experiments with lemmas leading to the Whitehead theorem. Note that the definition using `i : ℤ` is equivalent to that using `i ≥ -1` because `disk n` is empty for `n < 0`.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3ff9556b24875d78fb376051012e131ca68ff65d/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L79-L81
2. Can we shorten the proof of `colimitDiagram.map_comp`? Here we need to prove that, in a category, the composition of any finite number of morphisms is associative, i.e., a dependently typed [generalized associative law](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/2459697/prove-generalized-associative-law). Mathlib has `List.foldl_assoc` for the non-dependent associativity but I haven't been able to find the dependent version, so I made a long-winded proof here.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3ff9556b24875d78fb376051012e131ca68ff65d/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L120-L129

Any suggestions are appreciated!

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
Some other reviewer more expert in topology in mathlib than me should have another look.

I would think it would be much simpler if the numbering was with `ℕ` rather than `ℤ`. Then `sk 0` would be the space we start from, `sk 1` would be obtained by adding points, `sk 2` filling segments, etc.
Hi @jzxia, just checking in to ask what the status is. Are you planning to continue working on this PR? If not, please feel free to close it, or label it with `please-adopt`.

Hi @jcommelin, thank you for your interest. Dean Young (@unstablehomotopy ) and I are actively working on this PR and the Whitehead theorem. We’ve seriously considered [Joël Riou's suggestion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Three.20Whitehead.20theorems) for the API design and have now agreed on it. We’re optimistic about completing the definition (this PR) within a month.

@jzxia Great! When you are done, please remove the label `awaiting-author`.

> Some other reviewer more expert in topology in mathlib than me should have another look.
> 
> I would think it would be much simpler if the numbering was with `ℕ` rather than `ℤ`. Then `sk 0` would be the space we start from, `sk 1` would be obtained by adding points, `sk 2` filling segments, etc.

Re-numbering the skeletons is indeed convenient. I have done so and explained in the document that `sk n` actually means the `(n-1)`-dimensional skeleton, for `n ∈ ℕ`.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#16672~~

This construction should be part of a more general category theory API which would construct a functor `ℕ ⥤ C` from a sequence `obj : ℕ → C` and maps `obj n → obj (n + 1)`. You may freely use the (draft) code at https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/jriou_localization/Mathlib/Algebra/Homology/Factorizations/CM5a.lean#L76 (this should go in a file like `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Functor.OfSequence`.)
See https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/13223

Your API is very helpful. I have updated the definition of the topology on a relative CW-complex using your `Functor.OfSequence`.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3cfda01c25cc8ef045b74478e0ccc1f6dbb3571c/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L132-L134
This should be in the `RelativeCWComplex` namespace.

Thanks. This definition has now been renamed `RelativeCWComplex.toTopCat`.
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3cfda01c25cc8ef045b74478e0ccc1f6dbb3571c/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L132-L134

As a general remark, you may favour the following syntax:
```suggestion
  map n m n_le_m := skeletaInclusion' X n m <| Quiver.Hom.le n_le_m
```
Instead of `Quiver.Hom.le`, I think you could use `leOfHom`.
Thanks. Since I have updated the definition of the topology on a relative CW-complex using your `Functor.OfSequence`, this `colimitDiagram` is no longer needed.

This must be `TopCat.{0}`. I would be interested to know how difficult it would be to generalize definitions to `TopCat.{u}` so that in a certain future, we could relate simplicial sets in `Type u` with CW-complexes.{u}. (I do not want to push too much in this direction if it is painful to implement.)

Another (more important) suggestion is that with this definition of the basic cells, it may not be very easy to show that a sphere or a ball is a CW-complex. Topologically, as a substitute, we could use the topological realizations of the simplicial set inclusions `∂Δ[n] ⟶ Δ[n]` (these are isomorphic arrows in the category of topological spaces). Then, it would be much easier to show that the realization of simplicial sets are CW-complexes using the skeleton filtration (which would require a little work from the notions introduced in `AlgebraicTopology.SplitSimplicialObject`).

Then, in any case, I think that `AttachCells` should be generalized as `AttachGeneralizedCells` which would take as inputs `X`, `X'` and a continuous map of topological spaces (typically your `sphereInclusion`, but also the isomorphic arrows I am suggesting using simplicial sets).

Hi Joël.

Thanks very much for your time. I'd like to say I'm especially excited about the final suggestion you made, but first I want to explain how a sphere has a CW-approximation in this implementation:

If a CW-approximation exists for a space X homeomorphic to a space Y, then one exists for Y. Meanwhile the cube has a CW-approximation, merely one which features only one cell. Of course, one homeomorphism from the ∞-norm unit ball in ℝⁿ to the 2-norm unit ball in ℝⁿ is division by the 2-norm.

Meanwhile I'm really excited about your idea to include all of the basic shapes which make spheres and discs:

- the unit ball in the 2 norm its boundary
- the unit ball in the ∞ norm and its boundary
- the simplex and its boundary

I think we could start by defining a CW-complex as resulting from any of the three, but also to include homeomorphisms between Δⁿ, Dⁿ, and Iⁿ which restrict homeomorphisms of ∂Δⁿ, ∂Dⁿ, and ∂Iⁿ.

One further question is whether to include the p-norm unit ball for 1 ≤ p ≤ ∞.

Do you think that including all three kinds of attaching maps along with the mentioned homeomorphisms would satisfy the last issue?

One more thing I didn't mention is that CW-replacement and transport of πₙ (base-replacement) remains to be shown, but we thought it would be best to make this first smaller PR.

--Dean Young from the Lean 4 Zulip

If I want to show that topological realizations `|X|` of simplicial sets are CW-complexes, I would inductively attach a `n`-cell for each nondegenerate `n`-simplex. For example, for `|Δ[2]|`, this would mean starting with the empty set, add 3 points `0`, `1`, `2`, add 3 segments `[0,1]`, `[1,2]`, `[0,2]` to get a triangle (without its interior), and then attach a `2`-disk. This way, we get that the `2`-disk is a CW-complex.

Then, `Δ[n]/∂Δ[n]` has only two nondegenerate simplices, one `0`-simplex and one `n`-simplex. In this case attaching the `n` cell means identifying all the boundary points (which are on a sphere) of the unit ball, which gives a space that is homeomorphic (but not so obviously) to the n-dimensional sphere.

I do not think that the unit ball can be obtained using only one (or maybe two) cells. For the usual disk above, I have used `7` cells!

My more precise suggestion is to define a type `AttachGeneralizedCells X X' f` (where `f : A → B` gives the sort of "generalized" cells) which contains the data which says that `X'` is obtained from `X` by attaching `f`-cells. Then, if `f` and `g` are isomorphic arrows in `TopCat`, construct a bijection between `AttachGeneralizedCells X X' f` and `AttachGeneralizedCells X X' f'`. Then `AttachCells X X' n` can be defined as an abbreviation of this for the inclusion of the boundary of the ball. Then, the definition of relative CW-complexes is unchanged, but for their construction, we may now use more convenient types of cells using the bijections above. I do not think that more explicit types of cells are necessary besides the topological sphere/ball and the inclusions `|∂Δ[n]| → |Δ[n]|`.

Hi Joël,

Thank you for your review. I have updated my code according to your suggestions.

> I would be interested to know how difficult it would be to generalize definitions to `TopCat.{u}` so that in a certain future, we could relate simplicial sets in `Type u` with CW-complexes.{u}.

All definitions are now universe polymorphic. This was not difficult but I was unaware of its benefits, so thanks for reminding me.

> My more precise suggestion is to define a type `AttachGeneralizedCells X X' f`... Then `AttachCells X X' n` can be defined as an abbreviation

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3cfda01c25cc8ef045b74478e0ccc1f6dbb3571c/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L60

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3cfda01c25cc8ef045b74478e0ccc1f6dbb3571c/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L77-L79

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/3cfda01c25cc8ef045b74478e0ccc1f6dbb3571c/Mathlib/Topology/CWComplex.lean#L96-L97
make these notations local or scoped
Thanks. Now they are scoped notations.
I feel like this might be useful more generally than just CW-complexes. Should it move to a `TopCat` file?

I agree. (This might be useful for homology of `𝕊 n`, degree of maps from `𝕊 n` to `𝕊 n`, etc.)

Could we move `sphere`, `disk`, and their notations to `Topology/Category/TopCat/Basic.lean`? In the future, if there are more constructions of objects in `TopCat`, we could then move them to a new file.

Moving `sphere` and `disk` to `Topology/Category/TopCat/Basic.lean` leads to a conflict between the [Lean-3-style notation `⟪x, y⟫_𝕜` for inner product](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/2eb00cae7edccf4e54238db2cb4b0a7dff59fbdd/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Basic.lean#L85) and the (Lean 4) [notation `x |_ₗ U ⟪e⟫` for `TopCat.Presheaf.restrict`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/2eb00cae7edccf4e54238db2cb4b0a7dff59fbdd/Mathlib/Topology/Sheaves/Presheaf.lean#L113), and hence a syntax error in `Topology/Sheaves/Presheaf.lean`,

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/2eb00cae7edccf4e54238db2cb4b0a7dff59fbdd/Mathlib/Topology/Sheaves/Presheaf.lean#L125

with error message `error: ././././Mathlib/Topology/Sheaves/Presheaf.lean:125:12: unexpected token '⟫'; expected ','`.

These two notations are simultaneously in effect thanks to the import links shown below, where the thick red link is new, needed for the [`EuclideanSpace`](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/2eb00cae7edccf4e54238db2cb4b0a7dff59fbdd/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/PiL2.lean#L100) in the definition of `sphere` and `disk`.

![20240909_import_links_annotated](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/6995287f-2e8e-413f-a2bb-e5b1ea196f9e)

I tried making the Lean-3-style notation `⟪x, y⟫_𝕜` local, but this leads to more errors and I'm reluctant to modify existing code unrelated to this PR.

(There is also a conflict in `Topology/Category/TopCat/Limits/Basic.lean` where the tactic `by continuity` presumably gets overwhelmed by newly imported lemmas. This [can be fixed](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12502/commits/6ed65746447583d849c1af5cb71820d43284885d) by using the lemma `continuous_const` instead of the tactic.)

Could anyone help me decide the best way to resolve these conflicts? If Lean had a mechanism to `import` only a part of a file this would be easy, but I didn't find any instructions in the documentation.
Oh, that looks bad. Could you start a discussion on Zulip and then tag this PR as `awaiting-zulip`?
Sure. I've started [a Zulip discussion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Notation.20conflict.20in.20CW-complex.20PR).

The notation conflict is resolved by PR #16672.

Another conflict is in `Topology/Category/TopCat/Limits/Basic.lean`

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/e992840b976c4ebb76851871c8cbb559374331af/Mathlib/Topology/Category/TopCat/Limits/Basic.lean#L187

where the tactic `by continuity` presumably gets overwhelmed by newly imported definitions, resulting in an `aesop` timeout. I didn't look into the exact cause but I was able to fix it simply by using the theorem `continuous_const`

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/e992840b976c4ebb76851871c8cbb559374331af/Mathlib/Topology/Basic.lean#L1482-L1484

instead of the tactic. Is it OK to do the fix directly in the current PR (commit https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12502/commits/c4a602a942a0936368f1ff354e4214eeae8624c7 )?

With these two conflicts resolved, I was finally able to move `sphere` and `disk` into `TopCat/Basic.lean` (commit https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12502/commits/8f1214a13e171d1e37a59287f13522cf38a38a36 ).

The notation looks really weird here. I would expect
```suggestion
def sphereInclusion (n : ℤ) : 𝕊 n ⟶ 𝔻 (n + 1) where
```
...

...I think this should fix it
```suggestion
/-- `𝕊 n` denotes the `n`-sphere. -/
scoped notation "𝕊 "n:arg => sphere n

/-- `𝔻 n` denotes the `n`-disk. -/
scoped notation "𝔻 "n:arg => disk n
```
Thank you, this works. (I also changed `notation` to `prefix` so that `n` can be omitted here.)

Nit:
```suggestion
  attach_cells (n : ℕ) : RelativeCWComplex.AttachCells (sk n) (sk (n + 1)) (n - 1)
```

This looks really wrong in that you are stating equality of types. Is there any reason you are not doing
```suggestion
  sk_zero_empty : IsEmpty (sk 0)
```
`IsEmpty` indeed makes proofs simpler. Thanks!

Could you make this depend only on a *single* map `f` between topological spaces rather than a sequence of maps and an index `n`? It should not require too many changes to your code, but it would ease the future development of the API for `AttachGeneralizedCells`.

```suggestion
  isEmpty_sk_zero : IsEmpty (sk 0)
```

Relative CW-complexes should correspond to the addition, in a suitable order, first of points (i.e. pushouts by copies of the map `emptyset ⟶ {0}` (the target is the disk of dimension `0`), secondly filling "segments" (i.e. pushouts by copies of the map`S^0 ⟶ D^1`), and then `S^n ⟶ D^{n+1}`, etc.
Then, these definitions seem wrong to me: because of `Int.toNat`, `sphere (-1) = sphere 0` which is the disjoint union of two points, even though the sphere of dimension -1 should be empty.

I would strongly advocate the replacement of `ℤ` by `ℕ` everywhere in this PR. Then, the sequence of maps that are used to define what are `n`-cells should be defined by pattern matching: it should send `0` to the inclusion of the empty set in `D^0`, and `n + 1` to the inclusion of `S^n in D^{n+1}`.

Hi Joël, thanks for your suggestion!

> Then, these definitions seem wrong to me: because of `Int.toNat`, `sphere (-1) = sphere 0`

This is not the case. `sphere (-1)` is indeed empty, and `sphere 0` is the disjoint union of two points, exactly as what you'd expect:

```lean
#eval Int.toNat ((-1 : ℤ) + 1)  -- 0
#eval Int.toNat ((0 : ℤ) + 1)  -- 1
```

(Note that `Int.toNat <| n + 1` is the same as `Int.toNat (n + 1)`.)

While your suggestion on a pattern-matching definition is also feasible, it seems to me that the current definition greatly facilitates (among other things) the proof of the homotopy extension property of the pair `(𝔻 (n + 1), 𝕊 n)`, since the case `n = -1` need not be considered separately. Please have a look at [our proof](https://github.com/Chern-Weil/TheWhiteheadTheorem/blob/a9fce63b250d462d7330638c3f6dbb13d6dc83ff/CWComplex.lean#L396-L403).
We could perhaps make the definitions less confusing by replacing `Int.toNat <| n + 1` with `(n + 1).toNat` and replacing `Int.toNat n` with `n.toNat`.
Ah, ok. Sorry for my mistake.
I am not sure there is a need for this change. If `by continuity` works in reasonable time, there is no need to change it by an explicit term.

This change is required because, after moving `sphere` and `disk` into `TopCat/Basic.lean`, the tactic `continuity` (presumably) gets overwhelmed by newly imported definitions, resulting in the timeout error `tactic 'aesop' failed, failed to prove the goal after exhaustive search`. I didn't look into the exact cause but was able to fix this by using the explicit term `continuous_const`.

For details, please look at [this conversation](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12502#discussion_r1745581711).

This change is unrelated to CW-complexes but is required for this PR to build successfully. Should I open another PR for this change?
I believe that all occurrences of `Type` should be replaced by `Type u`. Otherwise, for example, a discrete topological space in `Type u` may not be a CW-complex.

Also, as you are using the colimit API for pushouts below, it would be more consistent to use the general category theory coproducts API instead of the type theoretic disjoint union. This would also remove the need for the verification of the continuity of some maps.
Thank you for these comments! Yes, using the categorical coproduct API has simplified the code, and is more consistent.

Linebreaks have to be after the infix operator:
```suggestion
  Limits.pushout.inl (Limits.Sigma.desc att.attachMaps) (Limits.Sigma.map fun _ ↦ sphereInclusion n) ≫
    att.iso_pushout.inv
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Topology): define (relative) CW-complexes

nodes.body:
Some other reviewer more expert in topology in mathlib than me should have another look.

I would think it would be much simpler if the numbering was with `ℕ` rather than `ℤ`. Then `sk 0` would be the space we start from, `sk 1` would be obtained by adding points, `sk 2` filling segments, etc.
Hi @jzxia, just checking in to ask what the status is. Are you planning to continue working on this PR? If not, please feel free to close it, or label it with `please-adopt`.

Hi @jcommelin, thank you for your interest. Dean Young (@unstablehomotopy ) and I are actively working on this PR and the Whitehead theorem. We’ve seriously considered [Joël Riou's suggestion](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/116395-maths/topic/Three.20Whitehead.20theorems) for the API design and have now agreed on it. We’re optimistic about completing the definition (this PR) within a month.

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ AttachCells`
`+ AttachCells.inclusion`
`+ AttachGeneralizedCells`
`+ CWComplex`
`+ RelativeCWComplex`
`+ disk`
`+ instance : Coe RelativeCWComplex TopCat where coe X := toTopCat X`
`+ skInclusion`
`+ sphere`
`+ sphereInclusion`
`+ toTopCat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
@jzxia Great! When you are done, please remove the label `awaiting-author`.

> Some other reviewer more expert in topology in mathlib than me should have another look.
> 
> I would think it would be much simpler if the numbering was with `ℕ` rather than `ℤ`. Then `sk 0` would be the space we start from, `sk 1` would be obtained by adding points, `sk 2` filling segments, etc.

Re-numbering the skeletons is indeed convenient. I have done so and explained in the document that `sk n` actually means the `(n-1)`-dimensional skeleton, for `n ∈ ℕ`.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(Topology/Category): fix imports in TopCat.Basic
